title: Bleasdale Circle Walking Route

images.title: Tom Richardson / Bleasdale Circle, Bleasdale
images.caption: Bleasdale Circle, Bleasdale. Taken looking west showing the ditch on the south side of the mound

images.caption: Stile near Bleasdale Circle. Stile with Heath-Robinson closing mechanism. Vicarage farm behind trees in distance.

images.caption: Packhorse Bridge, Brooks, Bleasdale

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Track to Hazlehurst Farm
images.caption: Track to Hazelehurst Farm. A 3-picture image made with Canon Photostitch. The distant fells are (l - r) Hazelehurst, Fairsnape and Parlick Pike.

images.title: David Medcalf / Holme House Farm, Bleasdale
images.caption: Holme House Farm. Nestling under the western flank of Fair Snape Fell. It is obvious how high the farmland reaches - and how the quality deteriorates with height.

images.title: Peter Bond / Clough Head Woods, Bleasdale
images.caption: Clough Head Woods

description: This walk visits the Bleasdale Stone Circle in the Forest of Bowland Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The circular walk starts at the church in the little village of Bleasdale, just to the south of the circle. Head north from here to Vicarage Farm and you can follow a track heading east to the circle. This Bronze Age circular earthwork is possibly aligned with the sunrise of the Summer Solstice. It's a very peaceful and picturesque spot to explore. The route then heads west back to the farm before turning north towards Admarsh Farm, Holme House and Hazelehurst. From here you turn south west to Clough Heads Wood before passing the Packhorse Bridge over the River Brock at Brooks and returning to Bleasdale.
